translated: The Collection of Long Discourses
The World
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā uruvelāyaṁ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.🔽Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā uruvelāyam viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhi rukkha mūle paṭhama abhisambuddhaḥ  tena khalu pana samayena bhagavā sattāham eka pallaṅkena nisinnaḥ hoti vimutti sukha paṭisavedī
translated: Once the Blessed One was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the Nerañjarā River at the root of the Bodhi tree, the tree of awakening, after his full enlightenment. 🔽At that time, for seven days the Blessed One remained in one session, experiencing the bliss of liberation.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā buddhacakkhunā lokaṁ volokesi.🔽Addasā kho bhagavā buddhacakkhunā volokento satte anekehi santāpehi santappamāne, anekehi ca pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāne—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā buddha cakkhunā lokam volokesi  addasā kho bhagavā buddha cakkhunā volokentaḥ satte anekehi santāpehi santappamāne anekehi ca pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāne
translated: Then, at the end of seven days, the Blessed One arose from that concentration and surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye.
As he surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye, he saw beings tormented by many kinds of suffering, burning with passion, hatred, and delusion.

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then, the Blessed One, having understood the meaning of this, on that occasion uttered this inspired utterance:
“This world is born to suffering,
Consumed by contact, it calls disease its own;
Whatever it thinks,
It becomes otherwise.
The world of beings is subject to change,
One who is intent on becoming delights in becoming.
What one delights in is fearful,

analyzed: yassa bhāyati tam dukkha  bhava vippahānāya kho
translated: What one fears is suffering.

original: Panidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vussati.🔽‘Ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhavena bhavassa vippamokkhamāhaṁsu, sabbe te avippamuttā bhavasmā’ti vadāmi.
analyzed: panidam brahmacariyam vussati  ye hi keci samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā bhavena bhavassa vippamokkham āhasu sabbe te a vippamuttāḥ bhavasma ati vadāmi
translated: This holy life is lived for the sake of the relinquishment of becoming.🔽‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins declare that through some kind of becoming one is freed from this world, all of them are not freed from this world, I say.

original: ‘Ye vā pana keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vibhavena bhavassa nissaraṇamāhaṁsu, sabbe te anissaṭā bhavasmā’ti vadāmi.
analyzed: ye vā pana keci samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā vibhavena bhavassa nissaraṇam āhasu sabbe te anissaṭāḥ bhavasma ati vadāmi
translated: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins declare that through some kind of becoming one is released from this world, all of them are not released from this world, I say.

original: Upadhiñhi paṭicca dukkhamidaṁ sambhoti, sabbupādānakkhayā natthi dukkhassa sambhavo.
analyzed: upadhim hi paṭicca dukkham idam sambhoti sabba upādāna kkhayā natthi dukkhassa sambhavaḥ
translated: For this suffering has becoming for its source, becoming for its origin; becoming is the cause, the source, the origin, the condition of this suffering.
See this world,

original: puthū avijjāya paretā bhūtā bhūtaratā aparimuttā;
analyzed: puthū avijjāya paretā bhūtā bhūta ratā a parimuttā
translated: with its many kinds of beings, bound by craving for becoming, not freed from the world of becoming.

original: ye hi keci bhavā sabbadhi sabbatthatāya sabbe te bhavā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammāti.🔽Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ,
analyzed: ye hi keci bhavā sabbadhi sabbatthatāya sabbe te bhavā aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā ati  evam etam yathā bhūta
translated: Whatever kinds of becoming there are, all are impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.
Thus it is with right wisdom🔽One sees this world as it really is.
Craving for becoming is abandoned,
One does not delight in non-becoming,
With the destruction of all craving,
there is no more suffering.
For the monk who has attained Nibbāna,
there is no further existence.
Mara is overcome, the battle is won,
the peerless one has gone beyond all becoming.”
The tenth.
The third sub-chapter on Nanda is finished.🔽The summary:
Action, Nanda, and Yasoja,
Sāriputta, and Kolita,
Pilinda, Kassapa, Piṇḍola,
and the craft, and the world—these are the ten.
